module.h: Should feminine nouns and their adjectives be slenderised after prepositions?
module.p:
The following prepositions govern a noun in the dative case –
à out of, aig at, air on, ann an in, bho from, de of, do to, fo under, gu to, le with, mu about, ri to, ro before, tro through

In traditional Gaelic, a feminine singular noun governed by one of these prepositions was slenderised (where possible) –
uinneag a window → tro uinneig through a window, tron uinneig through the window
coinneamh a meeting → aig coinneimh at a meeting, aig a’ choinneimh at the meeting

In addition, any adjectives following these nouns were slenderised in sympathy –
uinneag mhòr ghorm a big blue window → tro uinneig mhòir ghuirm through a big blue window, tron uinneig mhòir ghuirm through the big blue window
coinneamh cudromach an important meeting → aig coinneimh chudromaich at an important meeting, aig a’ choinneimh chudromaich at the important meeting

However, in contemporary vernacular Gaelic, there is a tendency to avoid this kind of slenderisation, especially in the absence of an article –
tro uinneag (mhòr) (ghorm)
tron uinneag (mhòr) (ghorm)
aig coinneamh (chudromach)
aig a’ choinneamh (chudromach)

Neither of these usages should be considered ungrammatical at this time –
If you are aiming for a more informal, conversational or modern style, avoid slenderisation of feminine nouns and their adjectives after prepositions.
If you are aiming for a more formal, literary or traditional style, embrace slenderisation of feminine nouns and their adjectives after prepositions.

Note finally that the following prepositions do not govern nouns in the dative case, so rules regarding slenderisation are different –
gun without, mar like (nominative)
chun to, far off, rè during, tarsainn across, fad throughout (genitive)
